#id=1
#text=In order for a bike to be rideable , its tires must be full of air .
#id=2
#text=If you ride over a sharp thorn or rock , you might get unlucky , and pierce one of your tires .
#id=3
#text=The air will rush out of the hole , and you will have a flat tire , often just called , a flat .
#id=4
#text=If this happens , you mus n't continue to ride ; you need to stop somewhere , and repair the tire .
#id=5
#text=First , you 'll need to remove the wheel that has the flat tire .
#id=6
#text=It is usually easier to remove the front wheel than the back , because of the gears in back .
#id=7
#text=Once you have the damaged wheel off the bike , you need to remove the tough outer part of the tire by prying it , little by little , off of the rim of the wheel .
#id=8
#text=The hole in the tough tire is not actually the problem ; it 's the hole in the inner tube that must be repaired .
#id=9
#text=Once you 've pried the tire off the rim , it is easy to pull out the floppy tube .
#text=Now you have to locate the hole .
#text=Sometimes the hole is very obvious , just by looking .
#text=Other times , you can submerge the tube under water , and look for bubbles .
#text=Once found , the hole can be easily patched using a patch kit .
#text=Test to make sure the hole is totally sealed before reassembling the wheel !
#text=If the repaired tube holds air well , you can put the tube in the tire , and get them back onto the rim of the wheel .
#text=Now , pedal fast , to make up for lost time !
